description:
Macadamia integrifolia, commonly known as the macadamia nut or Queensland nut, is an evergreen tree species native to southeast Queensland and northeast New South Wales in Australia. It belongs to the family Proteaceae.

The tree can grow up to 12 meters tall and has glossy, dark green, oblong leaves that are 10-30 cm long. The flowers are small, white, and clustered. The fruit is a hard-shelled nut, oval-shaped, and 2-4 cm in diameter. The nuts are encased in a green husk that splits open when ripe, revealing the edible kernel inside.

Macadamia integrifolia is valued for its nutritious and delicious nuts, which are high in monounsaturated fats, protein, and various vitamins and minerals. The nuts have a rich, buttery flavor and crunchy texture. Commercially, the trees are grown for their nuts, which are harvested, processed, and sold worldwide as a popular snack and ingredient in baked goods and confections.

The species is drought-tolerant and frost-sensitive, preferring subtropical climates. It is cultivated in many tropical and subtropical regions around the world, including Hawaii, California, South Africa, and parts of Central America.
